<http://Frase.io|Frase.io> (Clearscope/Marketmuse alternative) is running a lifetime deal on AppSumo right now: <https://appsumo.com/frase-black-friday-2020/> (not affiliated with them)

Just bought and ran a test for an article I'm planning and it looks decent for the price. If you're on the fence and want to see an example of the content briefs it creates, feel free to send me a DM with a keyword or topic, I can run it + send you a link to the brief.

elements.text: would you recommend it over Clearscope?

text: I've heard that clearscope gives you the most relevant content suggestions out of the whole bunch (that is, the technical part of these tools - topics, keywords, etc). Otherwise they work pretty much the same - scraping the results from top 10-20 results, and get their content structure (H2, H3). Frase can also scrape citations from studies (where references are made).

text:
Hi everyone! :wave::skin-tone-2: I’m writing a post on content marketing tools, which got me wondering about the average number of software tools a content marketer uses. (I’m betting it's a lot!) 

If you could share the number of tools you use one a regular basis – this includes SEO, editing, team comms, analysis, etc. – would really appreciate it!

And if you’re open to sharing more, I put out a quick survey here: <https://www.cognitoforms.com/ReferralRock/whatsoftwaretoolsdoyouuseincontentmarketing|https://www.cognitoforms.com/ReferralRock/whatsoftwaretoolsdoyouuseincontentmarketing>  

Thanks in advance!

Thanks in advance!

text: <@UJ4A0H534> Haven't done much in Frase yet, but wouldn't say it's better than Clearscope. Like most of these tools you still have to sift through the out-of-context data. Still, considering the lifetime deal cost less than one month of Clearscope, figured I'll give it a shot as I'm sure it'll get developed further.

text: Hi all! I'm looking into tools that can help me create a "choose your own adventure" or "tree-style" survey. The questions you are served will be based on your answers to the previous questions. The end goal is to offer content around our solution that can fit their needs best (between our 3 different products). I've found a tool called Cataboom, but not too much else. Does anyone else have experience building something similar?

elements.text: Hi all! I'm looking into tools that can help me create a "choose your own adventure" or "tree-style" survey. The questions you are served will be based on your answers to the previous questions. The end goal is to offer content around our solution that can fit their needs best (between our 3 different products). I've found a tool called Cataboom, but not too much else. Does anyone else have experience building something similar?

text: I think Paperform allows for that kind of functionality

elements.text: I think Paperform allows for that kind of functionality

text: <https://paperform.co/survey-forms/>

attachments.title: Create Survey Forms In Minutes
attachments.text: Create powerful surveys that interact with your respondents in real time.

text:
I just built one of these in Typeform — I've found it fairly user friendly. These are a few of the quizzes we've used for content marketing (first two very top of funnel, third more down funnel). It also integrates well with hubspot for contact management, can embed in your site if you choose.

<https://quorumquiz.typeform.com/to/kiiFWE>
<https://quorumquiz.typeform.com/to/gPMoTe>
<https://quorumquiz.typeform.com/to/tuEi4gHh>

The only downfall we've had is that Typeform doesn't validate emails are real. It requires you to follow email format (<mailto:xxxx@yyyyy.com|xxxx@yyyyy.com>) but doesn't require that to be a real address, so we got a lot of <mailto:no@no.com|no@no.com> in the first two top of funnel ones.

elements.text: I just built one of these in Typeform — I've found it fairly user friendly. text: <@U015WAHB532> SurveyMonkey can also handle it. The term you're after is 'branching logic' or 'skip logic' within surveys if that helps with Googlin'  ~ <https://www.surveymonkey.com/mp/tour/skiplogic/>

attachments.title: Skip Logic Branching: Conditional Survey Questions | SurveyMonkey
attachments.text: Skip logic is a feature that changes what question or page a respondent sees next based on how they answer the current question. Also known as conditional branching or branch logic, skip logic creates a custom path through the survey that varies based on a respondent’s answers. Learn more about Skip Logic at SurveyMonkey.
attachments.fallback: SurveyMonkey: Skip Logic Branching: Conditional Survey Questions | SurveyMonkey

elements.text: SurveyMonkey can also handle it. The term you're after is 'branching logic' or 'skip logic' within surveys if that helps with Googlin'  ~
